content.title: PLOOKUP
content.caption: A simplified polynomial protocol for lookup tables
content.description: A technique using lookup tables to enable logic on 8-bit binary strings, enabling efficient hash verification of non-SNARK-friendly hashes e.g. SHA-256

content.title: SHPLONK
content.caption: Efficient polynomial commitment schemes for multiple points and polynomials
content.description: This new scheme abstracts the Kate polynomial commitment scheme to enable one committed point to prove that a number of polynomials have been evaluated at each of a fixed set of points

content.title: PLONK
content.caption: Permutations over Lagrange-bases for Oecumenical Noninteractive arguments of Knowledge
content.description: A highly efficient universal SNARK, introducing a new circuit arithmetisation and the notion of 'selector polynomials', bound together by a permutation argument

content.title: TurboPLONK Benchmarks II
content.caption: 5x faster than Groth16 over Pedersen hashes
content.description: Demonstrating fast proof construction times over Pedersen hashes

content.title: TurboPLONK Benchmarks I
content.caption: The results of our PLONK implementation on MiMC Hashes
content.description: Aztec's PLONK implementation delivers fast proof construction times over MiMC hashes

content.title: Why Hashes Dominate in SNARKs
content.caption: Explaining why SNARKs are benchmarked by their performance over hashes
content.description: ZK-SNARK private assets are usually administrated using a pair of Merkle trees, a dense 'new note' tree and a sparse nullifier tree. This article explains the rationale for this architecture.
